text: Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Now, the survival part’s tricky because that’s the whole group, and some of the men, so, you look at the number total, it’s only, you know, a couple of months’ difference between the guys that get the drug and the guys that don’t. But within that group, there are some people that respond really well and really long who probably are getting much more than a couple of months, and there’s some people where it doesn’t do anything, and they’re probably getting nothing out of it. So, uh, the other thing they look at in the trials is something called a, sort of a risk reduction. So there’s pretty significant reduction in dying from prostate cancer if you’re on, if you take the drug. So in my experience, what I’ve seen is about a third of the men I give the drug to, their PSA drops, and they have a really long response that usually long means somewhere between, well, I’ve only been using it, you know, a couple of years now, but two to three years sometimes. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: One, one to three years, maybe, let’s say. Uh, another third of the guys, the PSA drops really nicely, and then starts to go back up usually six months or so, and then the third group of guys, usually the PSA is a readout. It just marches along. In your case, that’s going to be the primary thing for us because the bone, like I said, it’s hard to measure changes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, and the, the biggest fact from the drug was in men before chemotherapy, it’s probably just because they were earlier in their disease- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Not, not that there was anything different before or after. So, uh, the two drugs, about sixty plus percent of men respond overall. So that’s what I said. About two-thirds of the guys respond, and then one-third seems to have a long response, and one-third has a shorter response, and one-third don’t. Uh, in terms of how to pick which one of those two. Uh, for a while, I, I was picking Zytiga instead of Xtandi. Zytiga, the one complication with Zytiga, is you have to take a small dose of prednisone with it, uh, to kind of counterbalance how Zytiga works. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the one reason we would do that is because we had some trials, uh, that were after Zytiga. But the other reason was a tendency of less fatigue with the Zytiga than the Xtandi, in my experience. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Both drugs can cause fatigue. But it seems to be more common and often a little bit worse with Xtandi. So, uh, in my choosing those two, I have been choosing Zytiga, just for that reason. Uh, but the Xtandi is a little bit easier, because you just have to take Xtandi. You don’t have to take another drug.

text: Patient: Yeah. Yeah. My publicist is very on call. Doctor: Yeah. So anything new going on? Patient: No. I mean as far as how I feel. Doctor: How do you feel? Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: No new pains? No new issues urinating? Nothing else? Patient: No. I still wake up a couple of times a night you know and go but uh other than that I’m pretty active, play golf a couple of times a week. You know? Nothing slows me down. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I don’t have any bone pain. Don’t have any muscle pain per se. Uh. Doctor: So today we’re just going to go over stuff. And I, I mean it looks like unfortunately there’s been some changes that probably we’ll, we will have to call off the study. Patient: Oh is that right? Doctor: Yeah. Uh so the PSA to start with went up just a little, uh, so. Patient: It’s up around forty something isn’t it?

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And those are probably words that we opt to use. Um, If you have testicle cancer we could say remission Patient: Yeah. Doctor: because then you don’t see anything. text: Family Member: Whew. Doctor: Number two. It’s a limited treatment meaning you’re only going to get three infusions. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And how it works is we take blood out of him at the Red Cross. Family Member: Right. Doctor: They send it to Atlanta to kind of wake it up. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: Then, three days later, I get it back. He gets it in our infusion area and then that’s one treatment. And you do that a total of three times with a week in between. So within six weeks, you are finished with the therapy. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The PSA normally doesn’t change because we don’t expect it to kill the cells right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But what the heck? Your PSA is going down anyways.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So the theory is vitamin C in high doses may have a, let you have less side effects from the chemotherapy. Huh, at high doses, it may make the chemotherapy work better. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Old data says that sometimes if you take too much vitamin C when you’re getting chemotherapy it could protect the cells, in this case the cancer cells, which we don’t want to protect, and maybe make the chemo work less well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But have less side effects. Okay? So that’s why we have the dummy pill. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because most of what we’re looking for is how you feel. Oh, I’m having nausea. No. I’m not having nausea. Oh, this was a cakewalk. Oh, my fingers aren’t numb. Huh, my counts, huh, you know, are fine. Things that we’re going to be testing. So then we can sort of compare what blood test and symptoms are for those who actually get the vitamin C versus those who don’t. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have a fifty-fifty chance that you’re going to get the real stuff. Huh, you know, there is some flexibility. They want you here at least twice a week. But you know, if you’re going to go on holiday or something, you know, we can switch it. Huh, so far we know that giving high doses of vitamin C is safe. Huh, we haven’t seen many real extra side effects. But we don’t know the end of the answer. Does it help with side effects? Does it help activity? Or is there no difference? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so you would be potentially eligible for that. Huh, if you do a clinical trial, it does slow down a little bit when we get started. Okay? Huh, because we would first want to check your insurance company that they will pay for the clinical trial. You’re not on Medicare yet. You’re not sixty-five. Patient: Right.

text: Family Member: Oh yeah. Patient: So anyway back to the problem. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Your husband did what he does. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: And so this is gonna show us if if it worked? Doctor: Yeah so the CAT scan I think one of our concerns was that you also had the lymph node disease. Patient: Right. Yeah. Doctor: And at the last time that we did it before we started the Xofigo, really the lymph nodes were not a part of the problem. Okay. Doctor: If, however, the lymph nodes are growing or other areas that non-bone disease is showing progression, then we’ve got to address it. Patient: Start chemo or…

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think we’re probably hitting the bottom. Uh, which is okay. I, I think we have to sort of see how long we live there. Um. text: Family Member: I wanted, I want your input, uh but we couldn’t just give him that - because he is all at that level of three injections of testosterone, he’s a perfect candidate just for that immune thing just to see? (Beeping) Doctor: Well, the immune thing is normally I, I don’t. We’re not allowed to give anything unless it’s in a disease where it’s been approved- Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: because the cost is so very high, the hospital won’t let us do anything. So normally what we have to do is go through the insurance company, tell them what we wanted to do, they deny it, you write letters. So it’s not something that I can just do it tomorrow. Family Member: So you can’t ask-? Doctor: Now you, you know, who have, you’re a person of means, that maybe you could just pay for it, but I haven’t really, I don’t know what the avenue is to do that. (Laughs) Family Member: Well- Patient: Give, give that some thought, too. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Like maybe it’s, if you think it is worthwhile doing since I’m already trying with the testosterone to do it, uh. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You can follow a number of avenues. Doctor: I could ask the pharmacist if there’s a way that, you know, if the patient could actually just pay for it themselves and just get it.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
